segments.text: was more sort of a close-knit fraternity.
There weren't a whole lot of you guys, by the way, you know.
No.
That you had a chance probably to know everyone and much more camaraderie existed.
Do you feel as you got towards the end of your career that somehow or another that oceanography became more specialized and more impersonal?
Well, it became in one way more specialized and more fragmented
And then the sheer bulk of people that were involved necessarily meant less intimate associations with the few that were in the field in the early days.
And in the early days, much of the contacts would actually be some Europeans.
And Helen Hansen was through here early on.
at Grand, and a number of people in the early days.
And before Tommy Thompson built the laboratory, that's why he toured Europe to get an idea of what was going on in Europe.
And of course, he, being a true extrovert, knew people all over the world.

In your opinion, and sort of this particularly working in the north, which, you know, what you've done the most of, what nations did you particularly sort of admire in terms of their oceanographic ventures, besides ourselves?
Well, of course, the Norwegians have been tremendous in the field.
It started out with the dynamic meteorology, so that we had...
And Anson, and Spadrup, Mosby, a number of people there early on that were involved.
And certainly the dynamic part of it, Ekman and Bjerkenes and that group.
started out and the same fluid dynamics applies to the ocean as does the atmosphere in different ways.
But these people were very important.
The Japanese, of course, have been a long time involved in it.
They get mostly from the
Outside of Hidaka, who was over here, spent some time with us, and Uta, and some of the others.
They're mostly, a great many of them were involved in the fisheries, which is their lifeblood, as far as the ocean is concerned.
They've sort of lived off of the ocean.
We've had good contacts, in association with the Canadians.
This last year, I was up to the
to an affair honoring the physical oceanographers of Canada, the founding sort of physical oceanographers, in a way, of Canada.
And we had Tully from the West Coast, Bill Cameron, Hatchie from the
East Coast, and Picard, who came over after the war from England to Canada.
So just where I've worked, a lot of it has been with Canadians from time to time, both on the East Coast and the West Coast.
Now, I hate to ask you to hazard predictions.
I realize that's always not kosher.
But I'd like to sort of wind the interview down with a series of questions that students would like to ask you primarily.
What do you think was the single most important development in oceanography while you were involved in it during your long 40-odd year span?
That is an exceedingly difficult question to answer.
And I wouldn't look at a single development as much as a
in some ways, a unification of the field.
And I think a lot of this is sort of expressed in the book on the oceans.
And I think that these sub-disciplines, although they contribute really to the understanding
The final use that we make of those is going to require the cooperation of people of different disciplines.
This is still hard to get across in this present day.
But I think it doesn't mean that people have to be experts in all the different areas, because no one can.
But at least there should be free communication from one group to another.
There's far too much effort that has been spent on pursuing things that, from another viewpoint, would have been perfectly illogical.
So I think that, of course, there's no question about the advance in the technology here.
And I think in some ways the early days were a little bit like this skipper trying to get to the iceberg.
So we've come a long ways in that respect.
Was there any single amazing discovery in oceanography that seemed to amaze you the most?
in your career, anything that took you simply off balance?
I don't think that I was built to be caught too much by surprise.
There's been a lot of things that I've really appreciated that's come along, and the great developments and strides that have been
been made here.
But I think a lot of the sort of big strides have been from a certain amount of group effort.
And of course, with the increasing number of people, you don't see
the ones that particularly stand out head and shoulders above all others.
They're based on a fairly sound foundation, and so much of it has been in the nature of this cooperative work, even though some of them don't speak to each other yet.
That's always been a problem.
Now, excuse me.
Suppose you were simply to name one thing in your career that you thought you had enjoyed the most in oceanography.
What would you choose?
I've never worked on a job yet that I couldn't find some satisfaction in doing and some challenge all the way from my
Piling lumber to theoretical problems.
It's always been interesting to me.
And it would be hard for me to say, well, now, just what I would like to go out and do.
Now, what I'm doing at the moment is trying to...
round up a little bit more on the circulation of water properties in Puget Sound that I've been looking at since the early 30s out in the Sound, a little bit before.
And if we look at the ship canal problem.
So it's hard to say.
to pick out the real highlights.

I really appreciate the efforts that were put in by some very dedicated people that came out of a cooperation when we were in the emergency during the war, World War II, that really brought an awful lot of people together.
And I think above some of the personal

differences because there were an awful lot of personal differences in this group but i really think that they established then a a very good foundation for the future in oceanography and i think we can see the results of that that goes right back into the 40s right up this uh
present time.
We're still enjoying some of the fruits of the efforts of some of these dedicated individuals.
I take it that you would not change careers if you had to do all over again.
You would not remain with chemistry.
You'd go to oceanography.
Well, there's still chemistry in oceanography, although I haven't.
that I haven't done any legitimate chemistry for a long time.
It's one of the things that we started to do on the jobs I'd never finished.
At Woods' home, we thought if the situation deteriorated too much, we'd no longer be able to get our
standard water from Copenhagen, and so we made up our own at Woods Hole.

I was instrumental in going out on the soil on that and collecting up the water and bottling it up and so on, running some tests, which I never finished all the tests because the things got under control before it was necessary to push that.
than a routine job.
But I'm still concerned with the interaction of the physical and the biological in the water system, which is a problem that is far from being solved.
It's very, very complex.
And so I never looked a little bit at the Columbia River affluent at sea.
been involved in that.
But it's hard to pick out any one thing.
Or I don't think that I have any regret for the different steps I've taken over the years.
Is there anything else you'd like to add to the tape?

Well, I still think that anyone that is going ahead in science owes it to himself to be fairly broadly based, not that he is going to be an expert in any particular, in more than one particular facet.
But he certainly wants to have an appreciation of the interaction
of his sub-discipline with the others in some way or another.
The body has many different digits and so on, but they've all got to work together somehow.
Good enough.
I agree.
